segments.text: Did the church discourage or forbid relationships with your family and with your former friends?
And what did that have to do in the indoctrination process?
The unified family name that they go under sometimes, or they weren't at that time, I don't know if they use that name anymore or not.
is a reference to the fact that they believed the church to be the new family of God.
It's sort of a tribal concept.
Moon and his wife are seen as being the true parents of mankind, which Adam and Eve could not be because they had a premature sexual relationship.
And all of the members of the church are grafted into that family, in a sense, into the true family.
because of that, this becomes your real family.

And so relationships to the former family and former friends are only for the purpose, solely for the purpose of getting them involved in the church, getting them to make different kinds of commitments to the church, whether they will join or not, making financial commitments, material commitments, whatever they are.
Now, this, of course, if you believe that this is the true family, and it's the only thing to be involved with... Paul, no, don't do that now.
Then it makes sense that if you love these people, you'll want them to do this.
But it's a classic example of ends justifies the means, in that whatever you do to your family or for your family is only for the purpose of getting them involved with the church.
And so all real love and affection that you can have is channeled into pro-group activity.
And of course, the effect of that is to minimize and hopefully neutralize any influence from your formal life on people.
Of course, that's very difficult to do to a 100% kind of degree.
But I think this is sort of like a corporate takeover in some ways.
You only have to have 51% finally, although a person who's going to vacillate that much is not much good to the church.

but everyone has little corners of their psyche that resist control but even that resisting control becomes part of the control because you have guilt feelings about that and so that makes you that much stronger and so if you do if your parents do have some influence on you they do make you feel guilty about being involved or they do
make you feel anxiety, that ends up making your commitment to the church that much stronger because the negative response against that, the guilt, is part of what connects you to the church.
My relationship with most of my friends at the time I joined the church were very unsatisfactory.
The relationship with my girlfriend at that particular point was frustrating, not because we didn't care about each other a lot, but because she was going to the Ivory Coast the following year.
And also I was just not interested in being married.
While I wasn't ready to propose by any means, it was a different kind of relationship that I was looking forward to.
So there was really a lot of...
a lot of things contributing to the decline of the influence of my friends and my family in my life at that time, which, again, is typical of college students.
I mean, that's a big part of what college is about, a lot of what makes them vulnerable to begin with.
But the church certainly extends that.
Is this all the coffee?
Yeah.
She wants some, too.
Can you pour half of it in?
Sure.
Thank you.
That's fine.
You need so many people here.
I don't know if you're ready for this one.
Okay.
Explain how the divine principle differs from Christian theology.
Put in the new tape.
Briefly.
Briefly, right.
25 words or less.
Well, essentially, different people approach it different ways, but essentially Christianity is based on the concept of grace and forgiveness.
A sacrifice which, made by Christ, made it possible for people who were separated from God and sinners to be accepted on the basis of his sacrifice.
The idea of grace is a difficult one for many people.
The Jews have a real hard time with it.
Jewish theologians, that's the thing that gets in the way, I think, as much as anything else.
They feel like that's saying that God is not just.
And I can understand that.
And particularly a group that's had so much, oh, you didn't want to feel like this.
but has been treated so unjustly throughout the years, that's really hard for them to deal with.
But I think that's the essential basis of Christianity now.

The book of James has all the business about faith without works is dead, so you get the Protestant work ethic coming through there, and you have a lot of people in Protestantism probably who are trying to earn their salvation, whether they have that theology or not.
But the Unification Church is definitely an earn-your-salvation church.
I mean, that's a major theological point.
They call it the concept of indemnity, and it's a matter of making spiritual restitution for past sins.
And while Moon has, in some ways, done it for the whole world, each of us has to do it on our own.
And so you have processes of fasting and taking cold showers for long periods and doing lots of different things to pay indemnity for some kind of spiritual price.
So that's a huge difference.
There are carryovers from a lot of oriental cultural and religious ideas.
The importance of ancestors, the spiritual relationships, or the spirits of the ancestors are seen as being very important.
They must be released from their spiritual world prisons by special prayers and rituals.
I participated in some of those.
It was really wild.
Fascinating, fascinating.
The view of Christology, because of the idea of grace, is very different.

They see that the Christ was supposed to have been the conquering hero, not conquering in the sense of necessarily having to be a military conqueror, although military might play a role in the Unification Church's anti-communist stand, for sure.
I don't think in the long run that it's really a military takeover.
although elements in the church are certainly present where if it needed to go that direction, it could.
But the view of Christology, essentially, is that Christ came to take a bride and to establish the heavenly, the perfect family, true family, to become the true parent.
And that's the way they refer to him and his wife as the true parents.
So that's very different.
sort of millennialist, some similarities there.
There actually is a group of Jews, I think, that believes that the fall was essentially a sexual fall.
I forget which group, but I've heard that fact.
But in terms of differences from Christianity, I would say the business of grace versus works is probably the biggest one in the view of what Christ came to do.

The view toward the Bible, of course, they have to be willing to use the Bible rather than follow the Bible because these views that they have do really justice to a lot of the stuff that's in the text.
Did you believe that Reverend Maine was the Messiah?
Yeah, definitely.
All the members of the church.
I shouldn't say all.
It's rumored that one of the high-ranking theologians has her doubts about her.
But essentially, being a member of the church means accepting that fact, or at least living as though that were true.
Because that's what the whole thing is predicated on.
And they'll deny that, of course.
After you joined the group, where did you live?
I stayed in Manhattan, lived in the center in Manhattan for a while.
I actually went...

I was actually at home, that is to say in Newton, for a fairly long period during that first summer, and in the hospital for a while trying to get rid of an ulcer that I had picked up during the school year.
During that time, the church members visited me.
My dad tried to talk with me, but at that point my commitment was a young enough one
But it was pretty rabid.
And essentially, I didn't really want to talk with people about it too much.
I knew that I wasn't prepared to deal with all the questions that people were going to have.
I already knew a lot of what the objections would be from a traditional Christian point of view.
And my commitment was essentially a feeling commitment and one that I wasn't really willing to question at that point.
So after I went back from there, I think I went to Kansas City for a short time to try to help establish a center there.
I went back to Manhattan later on in the year.
It was thought for a while that I would try to go back to school and run for student body president, which of course would have been a real coup.
I would never have been elected if people were too weirded out by me wearing a tie at school and my beard shaved off.
And so I wouldn't have had a chance.
But in any event, that was considered.

I got a call to join the New Hoop Singers, which was a singing group that was established to accompany Moon on his speaking tours to the United States, the tour, the eight-city tour that started in Carnegie Hall in the fall of 1978.
And I was in that group until I left the church.
We toured with him then, we toured with him again.
I don't know if it was later that fall or in the next year.
I tell you, the dates from that whole era are very difficult for me to remember.
There are only two or three landmarks that I know what the dates were.
There were a couple of times when we had breaks that I remember.
We were in certain places and I remember events, but everything is very jumping together.
We traveled without a whole lot of sleep a lot of the time and were working very hard all the time.
Never had enough time to rehearse.
It was artistically extremely frustrating.
Although I had some creative moments while I was in the church.
I think that that kind of discipline and intensity can in some instances be a boon to creativity because there's so much structure.
And I think most artists will agree.
Like for Stravinsky, he would set a problem, and once the problem was solved, the piece was composed.
And so establishing a structure within which one has to work is one of the first and maybe the most important part of having something happen creatively.
And I did some interesting arranging while I was in the church, some things that I still like a lot.
Not much composing.
It was almost all arranging, as I recall.
How is the structured life used to keep members in the church and to get rid of any doubt that they're having?
Well, you know rituals in any culture
serve to kind of give one stability and structure and help you make one step to the next without having to stop and think about the next one.
That's parallel.
You know, if you have to ask why about everything you do, then you don't get anything done.
And within the Church,

you know going working very hard many many hours all the time seven days a week with very very few breaks certainly no long vacations if there was ever a break it would be like a day-long trip or something like that or and often it's not a big festival at one of those big homes either on the west coast or the east coast or wherever you happen to be um
What that serves to do is give you some stability on a day-to-day basis and small tasks to accomplish.
And, of course, that's very important within the theology of the church, too.
All of these little tasks have their spiritual role and their spiritual component.
But it also keeps you from having time to think very much on your own.
You're always working with other members.
The hardest, acknowledged by the church, is the hardest thing is to have a person go out and try to establish a center on his or her own.
And that would be hard in any event, because it's just hard to do that sort of thing alone.
But most of the time, the people live in groups, and particularly fundraising and that sort of thing is done in groups because it just takes a lot to keep each other built up.
I think the normal peer group pressure is used.
I mean, it's peer group pressure the way you see it in other things.
The only thing is that what it's reinforcing is a very intense manipulation that goes far beyond what group pressure can ordinarily influence.
Were you involved in a lot of fundraising activity?
Some.
I was never involved on what they called a mobile fundraising team, MFT.
But while I was with the New Group Singers, we did a fair amount of fundraising.
I was never a particularly successful fundraiser.
I was pretty average.
I'd average $100 a day.
selling flowers or something like that, or between, I would say, 70 and 120.
I did get somewhat better as time went on.
The biggest day I ever had, I think, was $200.
But there are some people who can do $500 a day for 30 days in a row.
I don't think that the fundraising is carrying on to the same degree now.
They've become much more involved with the business.
Of course, all this stuff about the fishing industry that they were trying to work their way in and have, I think, pretty effectively worked their way in.
They were providing cleaning services, doing all sorts of stuff.
If they would have followed Moon's advice, he wanted them to try to corner the flower market.
in the 70s.
And if they would have followed his advice and really been organized about it, they could have done quite a bit, I think.
Because the thing is, you know, essentially they don't pay the labor at all.
And they order in tremendous bulk, and they sold flowers to people for donations.
You know, a dollar for a carnation kind of stuff.
So the profit was just unbelievable.
And, of course, that's why he ended up having so much money.
But, no, I wasn't involved with that much money.
Do you think the fundraising activities helped strengthen the group's cohesiveness?
or help the members identify more with the group?
Yeah.
Fundraising is very difficult work.
I mean, you're on your feet for 12 to 16 hours a day.
It's unbelievably difficult.
And running a lot of the time, and you're having to meet people, and you're having to sell this group to people all the time.
And a lot of the fundraisers lied.
As a matter of fact, I think all of them probably.
I can't imagine how a person could have been a successful fundraiser without doing quite a bit of lying.
So you were involved in the process of deceiving the world to try to take away its money to build up the Heavenly Kingdom all the time.
So yeah, it was...
If you lived through it...
And there's some people who didn't.
I mean, I know of some people who cracked under the strain.
And the church would just send them home.
You know, they have a mental breakdown, something like that.
They'd just send them home.
No money, no nothing.
Oh, gosh.
It was some terrible tragedy.
The first member from Kansas who joined was on a roll of fundraising.
He finally had a mental breakdown while fundraising barefoot in the snow on the East Coast.
And they just sent him home.
He ended up in Topeka State Mental Institution because his family didn't have enough money.
Yeah.
Yeah, pretty tragic.
Anyway.
But I would say that it does build up the group and also...

Yes, I do think that those activities, and the witnessing was carried on in much the same manner, but witnessing the members always found much easier to do or much more grateful because they were in the process of actually engendering positive responses, people who would join the church and that kind of thing.
But yeah, they did a lot to build the members up.
I mean, that was the kind of activity, both of those were the kind of activity where you were putting your faith on the line all the time in difficult actions.
And that's what builds a person up.

what was your reaction to reverend main's vast personal wealth and did the church try to justify it at all well yeah the justification was built in to the ideology in the sense that the true parent of mankind deserved to have everything and that
You know, that was never an issue.
It's very interesting.
I know for the people outside, boy, how could he have all this and you have nothing?
And they obviously don't understand the mentality.
I mean, I think that's one of the best examples I can think of of people just being incapable of understanding the extent to which the mind control existed in the group.
But that was never a question for me, and I don't know anyone for whom it was a question.
Maybe one or two people who were kind of marginal and people who...
in one case I know left the church, in the other case I don't know, on their own, that is to say, deprogramming.
And that sort of thing happened too.

A lot of people looking at the church from the outside, they have to say it's either you have 100% control over them and they can't do anything on their own, you have to let them go by deprogramming, or the other extreme liberal ideas,
Well, it's just like a convent.
You know, well, neither of those is really true.
People do leave on their own, and there were greater and lesser degrees of control, and the person exerted, in a sense, exerted the church's control over themselves.
But on the issue of how much money he had, that was just never a big deal.
And the thing is, is that...
There was in some ways a beautiful quality about the simple lifestyle.
I mean, I think that a simple lifestyle can do wonderful things for a person's sense of material value.
I will never again be so hung up about money.
I can recall feeling very guilty when I bought myself a 59-cent Coke with money that I had raised in fundraising.
And there were some members who justified it in saying, you have to have those kinds of things from time to time.
And I think those were the wise ones, probably.
But the thing is, when I left, I just realized that things are for using.
And this is not universal, but it was a lesson that I took from it.
Things are for using.
They're for enjoying.
They are important.
But they are not important in and of themselves, but they are important because of the relationships that can be developed and enjoyed and the life experiences that can be had with them.
That's all they're for.
And I think there was probably a sense of that in the church, at least with some of the better people who I knew.
And like when he, when Moon would throw a party and would buy Big Macs for everybody, he loved McDonald's.
He went to McDonald's all the time, and he would buy Big Macs for everybody, and it was like communion.
You know, some very beautiful, intense experiences.
Or they would fix Korean food, and I still love Korean food to this day.
And we would share that, and it was so wonderful, so beautiful.
He would give gifts, like ties, to the guys who finished the training session, or take them to New York and buy them all new suits, or something like that.
And there was a real...
Yeah, it was very manipulative, but there were some very positive feelings and some, you know, that people didn't take things for themselves.
I don't know any instances of graft, for example, and that sort of thing while I was in the church.
I don't know of people taking money that should have belonged to the church.
I'm sure there were some, you know.
You have somebody who left the church and took with them a whole bunch of money or something like that.
But essentially, people didn't get hung up on material as much.
The church was very hung up on material, and they were trying to get as much of it as they could, for sure.
But in terms of on a personal level, I think material things were important because they could be gifts, or they were important because who had given them to them.
And there were some attractive things about that.
But as far as resentment against Moon, I certainly never experienced any, and I don't know if there were members who did or not.
That's not to say that I think it was appropriate, that looking back now I think it's appropriate or that it's right that he had those things.
If he were who he said he was, who they said he was, you know, I suppose that it would be okay.
I don't think...
that a person who was the Messiah would have that much stuff and would treat it that way, but I'm not in a position to make that kind of judgment.
What was your diet like in the center and on tour?
A lot of rice.
Very little meat, of course.
We had some cooks who, having had experience with macrobiotics or natural foods, would cook a lot of vegetables and we'd have a lot of fruit.
Sometimes we ate fairly well from that point of view.
Sometimes we had people who knew nothing about it and all we had was rice and soybeans, a lot of soybeans as well.
Very little meat, but that was because it was expensive.
I don't think that that was a deliberate technique to bring down the line through deprivation of proteins.
Although some of that may have happened, I don't know.
There was a time when the New Hope singers were so poor, we had to raise our own money as well as rehearsing and that kind of stuff.
That was a common technique within the church.
Make each group support itself, plus send in a lot of money.
We lived for a week on peanut butter.
while we were on tour.
But essentially it was sort of...
I don't know what it would be comparable to.
Really bad school cafeteria a lot of the time.
Now, I've heard some people say that there was some protein deprivation going on.
I think that's possible.
I don't think that it was a policy of protein deprivation through the church.
While we were in Japan and Korea, we ate better than we did when we were in the States.
They made sure that we were well fed all the time.
Which meant white rice most of the time.
I think a lot of us who were redder had brown rice or some other thing.
But white rice is what you serve to companies, so that's what we got.
We had some really good meals while we were in, but mostly food was very functional.
Any thoughts?
Lots of rice and lots of coffee.
What were the circumstances surrounding your leaving the church?
Tape number four.
In 1973, in October, we had just returned from Japan.
We had had some really incredible experiences in Japan and Korea.
We played for like a million people.
I'm sure it was in the range of a million people.
The estimates went from 600,000, which I think was people trying to minimize it, I really do, because it was people as far as the eye could see.
I mean, it was unbelievable.
Unbelievable.
They were not all members by any means, don't get me wrong.
By no stretch of the imagination were they even, you know, the church members were a small minority.
It was a political rally that was staged.
And he used all of these Westerners, members of the church, to travel around Korea trying to get people to come to this thing, passing out handbills and stuff like that.
And so the Korean people were very interested.
Who is this Korean man who has all of these Westerners running around?
You know, it was a good ploy on his part.
And I'm sure he helped his stock in Korea quite a bit, particularly with the government.
But anyway, had a lot of those kinds of experiences.
We came back to the United States.
We were supposed to have gone through the singing group I was in, that is.
We were supposed to have gone through a training session in New York, and then we would go back into rehearsals.
Some would be given other assignments, and the group would be a little bit reorganized and continue traveling and performing.

My grandmother happened to be fairly ill and in the hospital at the time, and I hadn't seen her in years and hadn't been, since I had joined the church two and a half years, and hadn't been with my family for quite a while.
And so when they discovered that, since ancestors are very important, they allowed me to go home.
Now I had a dream before I left, the night before I left, that my parents were going to try to deprogram me, and I was responsible.
to tell my able.
But I knew if I did, I wouldn't get to go.
So one of the very few insubordinate things that I ever did when I was in the church, a minor thing to a degree, but, well, they wouldn't consider it minor, of course.
But I did go home.
My parents had tried to talk me into leaving the church before.
My dad had flown out, had spent Christmas with me that year, the previous year, 72.
He spent Christmas with me instead of with the family before I left for Japan and Korea because he tried to talk me to stay.
He never even really raised the subject.
I mean, he knew from the discussions we were having that it was evil, but what we did, we were able to spend a little bit of time together since he had come out to see me.
The church respected that.
I mean, they realized that he had made a tremendous sacrifice to come out to see me.
And so they were willing to let me spend some time with them.
Although certainly not days on end, you know, but a few hours here, a couple hours there.
Anyway, so they allowed me to go home.
And she was out in Colorado Springs, so I flew into Wichita and drove out to Colorado Springs with my folks.
I don't think the church knew that I was in Colorado Springs.
I had thought that she was in the hospital in Newman, which is where my parents live, in Newman, Kansas.
So I don't think they knew where I was.
I don't recall that detail very well.
But in any event, we went out and we visited my grandmother in the springs.
And I have an aunt and uncle who live there.
They told me that they had a Sunday school party that was being held up in the mountains, and they needed to take up some pots and pans.
So we went out to dinner at a cafeteria, and then we took off up in the mountains, and I was exhausted, and I fell asleep in the back seat.

And so I got into the, went into this house, cabin up in the mountains and met some people from the Sunday school class and went downstairs and my dad introduced me to Ted Patrick and I found out the party was for me.
Very interesting.
This was in the evening.
I don't really recall what time, I suppose.
8, 9 o'clock, 10 o'clock.
I don't really know.
Anyway, there were some big guys there.
And I knew that I was not going to be able to walk out the door.
And I also knew, they were up in the mountains, and I knew, you know, I had no idea where.
I just, I had no idea at all.
I had fallen asleep, you know, so I was, could have been in Wyoming, probably, or New Mexico.
So I sat down there, and Patrick was using his standard lines.
He would sit there and ask me questions about the church, but he had his own answers, you know, so he'd ask me a question, I would give him the standard line, and he would say, no, this, this, this.
And he baits people.
He would read passages from the Bible, like the one about, let no man have you called him father, or this sort of thing.
And he would insert Moon's name.
Do not let Sun Myung Moon have him call you father.
It's just to make you angry.
And in some ways, that's a pretty good tact, just because once you start getting angry, then you start drawing on your own personal resources.

And once you start doing that, then you begin to realize the distance between, the member begins to realize the distance between his or her own personal feelings and own morals and own standards of judgment in those of the church.
And that's the beginning of the process of breaking away.
I was a little...
I mean, I knew what this was going to be like.
I had a sense.
We had already talked about it in the church, and I had heard stories from people.
And also, I kind of had a sense of what it would be like.
I mean, I just could imagine it in a way.
And so I essentially faked through the first evening.
And I knew I was supposed to have an emotional breakdown and embrace my parents and tell them I had to go back to the church, and I did.
And so they were real happy, and Patrick was happy.
He was like, oh, he's going to be fine.
He'll be fine.
Well, I don't know if they had a sense of how much I was faking or not.
I don't really think they did.
I've been through enough deprogrammings to have a pretty good sense of what happens on the other side.
And I think they thought it was over, that there might be some problems that they didn't know.
But anyway, so Patrick left the next morning.
He left a couple of former members there with my family and my aunt and uncle and their friends who were serving as security.
I knew that they were going to want me to sign a statement saying that if I went back to the church I wanted them to, I gave them permission to have police come in and take me out.
And I knew that in order for that to have any kind of legal binding effect, they were going to have to have at least a signature from the media.
You know what I'm talking about.
You know what I'm talking about.
Notary.
Yeah.
So I knew they had to have at least a notary, too.
And so I thought what I would try to do was get them to take me to a law enforcement office to sign it.
or at the very least have a notary public come out.
I figured that was the contact with the outside world, the objective outside world.
The next morning I saw that we were right close to Pikes Peak.

And so I figured if that fails, then I would just simply take one of the chairs from the living room and throw it through the window and myself after it and I'll head for the peak and certainly be able to get out somehow, you know, get forestry service or something.
So that was my plan.
Well, I was able to persuade them to take me to a law enforcement office, a local sheriff's office, to sign this paper.
We walked into the sheriff's office.
I went up there on a Thursday night, and this was Saturday.
I went to the sheriff's office Saturday morning.
And I walked in, and I told the guy, listen, these people are holding me against my will.
They're trying to force me to change my religious beliefs, and you are responsible for protecting me.
My dad nearly had a heart attack.
I have never seen him so close.
And the guys were just livid, the guys who came along with him.
There were two guys.
And all three of them were just going crazy.
They were screaming and yelling.
And they just couldn't believe this was happening.
And I was sitting there very coolly trying to explain to this guy.
He happened to be the undersheriff.
Why it was that he had to give me asylum.
I said, I'll be happy to talk to a psychiatrist.
I'll be happy to talk to lawyers or whatever, but do not let them take me back because they're holding me against my will.
Well, there was a children of God compound not too far from there.

And when they started talking about brainwashing, and he saw that I was sitting there very coolly, calmly, just talking to him very normally, while my dad was on his knees pleading with me to go back, and these other guys were screaming their heads off.
I think he realized that probably something like that was involved.
He didn't want to get involved in any of that, so he let them carry me out of there.
And he was really liable.
I mean, we could have sued him up one side and down the other so bad.
Well, at that point, I knew that it was probably not my sense of mind anymore, that I had blown my best chance.
And that if there was a chance to escape, I would, on the other hand, if the truth's the truth, you know.
So we sit and talk about it.
And if it's the truth, fine.
I don't have to worry about it.
And I figured that I would end up letting them get much closer to what I really believed and just be much more open with them.
And so I did.
And what happened was, during the next week then, these people who were staying with me, they hadn't been in the church nearly as long as I had, didn't know half of what I knew.
Patrick didn't know half of what I knew about the church, I don't think.
He was showing me films and telling me all this terrible stuff.
And I was saying to myself, you don't know nothing.
Having been in Korea and Japan, I had heard some pretty weird stuff.
I had been traveling with women.
I had served as a bodyguard for them.
They just had no idea the kind of things I had been doing or the kind of stuff I knew about the church.
So as time went on, we read Helter Skelter and parts of Helter Skelter.
And I recognize some similarities, and there really are.
I think that people who say that that's just scare tactics are wrong.
I think that there are some similarities.
very obvious similarities between the two groups.
The Jones People's Temple, same thing.
There are a lot of similarities.
The ideologies are different, and some of the tactics are different.
They tend to be much more violent, of course, than the Unification Church.
But the same kind of control exists, I firmly believe, and I think could be demonstrated by looking at psychological profiles.

Anyway, after a few days, one time we were sitting down, and I was reading a passage from Matthew, a business about how Jesus is accusing the Pharisees of being whitewashed tombs, and talking about how, you know, you make these proselytes, you know, more fit for hell than yourselves.
You know, the passage I'm talking about, Matthew 24, something like that.

And I realized that because of the deception that the church engaged in, and I was involved in it, and I was very aware of it, and it bothered me on a personal level, even though I could understand the reasoning for it and was committed to it as a committed member of the church.
I realized how a person could really hold that up against the church and say, you know, that's a real drawback.
And the first time I read it, it really affected me emotionally very deeply.
The second time I read it, much less than the third time, it didn't affect me at all.
But at that point, I was aware enough of my own responses emotionally.
But suddenly I was thinking, well, that's really wrong.
It really shouldn't be that way.
That's not the kind of person I am.
And I really resented the kind of emotional manipulation that I had been subjected to and was subjecting myself to as a member of the Church.

And I began to, and I realized very quickly, and it was something I had probably known but not allowed myself to be conscious of, was that my commitment to the Church was essentially a manipulated one.
It was not an authentic one, as I said before, one that was carefully reasoned and thought out and made from the basis of a lot of choices.
It was one that I was forced into, and coerced into, and deceived into, most importantly.
And that made me really angry.
And all of a sudden, I just had this overwhelming urge to feel my own feelings.
Now, that may sound very bizarre to you, but I really felt like I had been in the process of only feeling what the Church wanted me to feel for such a long time.
And I had a real desire just to feel my own feelings.
And it was like there was anger there, but I wasn't experiencing it.
It was kind of a strange, almost dissociation.
And in order just to feel...
My own anger and my own hurt, I started hitting the wall.
I still have scars on my hands from hitting the wall in that basement.
And my hands started bleeding and I started sobbing, just terrible choke, you know, horrible choke.
Choked sobs, just bleh.
That was it.
At that point, I had a tremendous sense of sadness that I knew that I could never be the same.
There was an element of relief to it, but it was a great deal of grieving.
It was sort of like realizing that your marriage isn't going to work.
Something you've committed yourself to forever is just not going to work.
It was very painful, but I think even if I would have gone back to the church, I would have loved it.

It's interesting, since that time, I haven't had this dream for a long time, and the dreams have changed, but from that time on, for a number of years, I dreamed about going back to the church and going on with life.

It's like I knew that even though there was attraction for me there, I had some wonderful experiences there and some beautiful friends, wonderful people, and some very beautiful experiences, very intense, of the kind that only come in that kind of intense encounter.
Not to say that kind of intense manipulation.
I think it can happen in other ways.
And I've certainly had many beautiful experiences since.
All the more beautiful because they happened in and of themselves among adults who had freedom of choice.
Even so, there were still attractions and things that I had liked about it and people who I had loved that I could never go back and stay.
The whole process was about, we were in that cabin for about two weeks.
After five days, I was done.
I had left the church inside.
Not to say that I would never have gone back at that point, but like I said, I think I would have left eventually.
After two weeks,
I think I was very settled.
They weren't secure about me at all, and of course, after the trick I pulled at the Hunter Sheriff's Office, I don't blame them.

But, oh, less than a month later, they let me out in the car by myself, and I had a sense, pulling up to a stop sign in Newton, well, I know that I could head down the street and be in Wichita at the center in an hour, and just...
It was kind of fun to know that I could do it if I wanted to, but I knew I didn't want to.
That was it.
For me, it was a very clean break, an emotional abreaction.
But for many people it's not, and it's too bad.
Because it makes it much easier, like I said, dealing with the guilt and the feeling of responsibility.
As a matter of fact, I even had one person say, you know, you really don't take responsibility for that experience.
And I had just to admit to myself, no, there's a way in which I don't.
I feel like a lot of the responsibility for me getting involved lies with the Church.
And I won't say none of it lies with me.
And not that I didn't learn a lot of valuable things, but the sacrifices were extraordinary.
And the commitment, extraordinary as it was, and as much of a learning experience as it was, and you can never say this was better or that was worse about your life.
I mean, I sort of take it as a piece and feel like in the whole I've been very lucky.
Still, I think it was primarily a negative lesson in my life.
And while I would not say that the Unification Church is something that should be outlawed,
I think that there needs to be sort of a truth in advertising kind of enforcement that happens by groups like that.
And I don't know how much the government can do.
It's a real quandary.
That's why I've done a fair amount of lecturing and stuff like that to try to help educate people.
I feel like that's the best thing that can happen.
But the level of manipulation that goes on in coercion in that group and the level of deception that is involved is really not evident to the outside world.
People who've not been through it, I don't think, can really appreciate it.
And I don't say that about a lot of things.
I firmly believe in the value of symbolism and the ability of people to share experiences through art, for example, and stuff.
And I hope someday to write an opera which will help people understand.
I wouldn't even write it just for the... to be anti-cult.
Just to say, this is a very intense human experience which is worth trying to explore through the different kinds of symbols that are available to artists.
But I think, essentially...
You know, it's like trying to make the association between
a lake and the ocean.
The two are both bodies of water, but they're so dissimilar.
When I'm speaking, I have such a hard time coming up with metaphors that will help people understand.
I use a Chinese fire drill to talk about group pressure and how differently people behave than they would by themselves.
But it's really hard.
Most people just can't imagine letting somebody else decide who they're going to marry.
I mean, it takes them into the realm of fantasy.
And they can't imagine how that can really happen.
And they don't understand the tremendous psychological dynamics that have to be in play in order for that to take place.
But I was looking forward to it.
I was a committed pacifist who had gone through a very painful transition from wanting to be a Marine to finally rejecting violence as a means of solving human problems.
And that was a very carefully-reasoned and mature choice that I had made.
I say mature, maybe rather presumptuously, but it was certainly the most difficult process I had gone through.
And I tossed it all over in the matter, really, of a few minutes, when I joined the Unification Church.
was willing to go to war for South Korea, not even just for the United States.
So it's a really extraordinary thing, and there's hardly any explaining it.
It's just sort of a phenomenon.
I'm not suggesting that people become involved to experience it, but to see the degree to which an individual can
give up their own choice-making responsibility and opportunities is really amazing.
And it's a frightening lesson.
I think that the parallels that have been drawn between it and Chinese brainwashing, although I think brainwashing is a very bad term, because it's not really a washing of the brain.
The Chinese think that they wash away the old character and install a new one.
That's their materialist point of view.
It's evident from the people who go through that process and come out that, at least on the short term, that's not what happens.
Because most people who come out end up being much more similar to what they were before they went through it than what they were after the process.

and certainly you don't have the kind of physical torture that some of the Westerners went through, but if you examine the process that the Chinese intellectuals went through in China, the similarities between that and what happens with the Unification Church are very frightening.
If you take away the element of enforced participation, which happens in China,
The Unification Church gets participation through deception, and giving people something, or making them think they're getting something that they're not, other than what they're getting.
If you're willing to make that substitution, then the similarities are unmistakable.
